title: Get started
text: Besides required packages, SEMgraph suggests use R package org.Hs.eg.db Bioconductor project, gene ID conversion. SEMgraph uses entrez IDs avoid special chatacters (hyphens slashes), can use official gene symbols labels. package SEMdata contains useful high-throughput sequencing data, reference networks, pathways SEMgraph training:
code: if (!require("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE))     install.packages("BiocManager")  BiocManager::install("org.Hs.eg.db") #devtools::install_github("fernandoPalluzzi/SEMdata")

title: Get started
text: Load necessary libraries run tutorial: SEMdata provides ALS RNA-seq dataset 139 cases 21 healthy controls, Tam O.H. et al., 2019 (GEO accession: GSE124439). Raw data pre-processed applying batch effect correction remove data production center brain area biases. Using multidimensional scaling-based clustering, ALS-specific HC-specific clusters generated. Misclassified samples blacklisted removed dataset. Since expression many genes significantly different Gaussian, apply nonparanormal transform relax normality assumption.
code: library(SEMgraph) library(SEMdata) library(org.Hs.eg.db) # ALS input graph summary(alsData$graph) ## IGRAPH 5d44052 DNW- 32 47 --  ## + attr: name (v/c), weight (e/n) # Label graph: Convert Entrez identifiers to gene symbols V(alsData$graph)$label <- mapIds(org.Hs.eg.db, V(alsData$graph)$name,                                  column = 'SYMBOL',                                  keytype = 'ENTREZID')  # ALS RNA-seq expression data dim(alsData$exprs) ## [1]   160 17695 # group = {1: case, 0: control} vector table(alsData$group) ##  ##   0   1  ##  21 139 # Nonparanormal transform data.npn <- transformData(alsData$exprs)$data ## Conducting the nonparanormal transformation via shrunkun ECDF...done.

title: Get started
text: SEMgraph offers three main modes model fitting: () common model fitting, (ii) node perturbation evaluation, (iii) edge perturbation evaluation. SEMgraph automatically take care applying shrinkage methods case high dimensionality (#variables >> #subjects), heuristics parallelization settings large graphs. addition, perturbation evaluation enables extraction differentially regulated nodes (DRNs) edges (DREs).
code: # ALS model fitting (sem0) # The whole dataset is used to fit the model and perturbation is not evaluated (group = NULL) sem0 <- SEMrun(graph = alsData$graph, data = data.npn) ## NLMINB solver ended normally after 1 iterations  ##  ## deviance/df: 10.92504  srmr: 0.2858859 # verbose output #summary(sem0$fit) # short output head(parameterEstimates(sem0$fit)) ##     lhs op  rhs    est    se      z pvalue ci.lower ci.upper ## 1 10452  ~ 6647  0.037 0.079  0.466  0.641   -0.118    0.192 ## 2  1432  ~ 5606  0.397 0.082  4.839  0.000    0.236    0.557 ## 3  1432  ~ 5608  0.578 0.082  7.047  0.000    0.417    0.738 ## 4  1616  ~ 7132  0.245 0.110  2.236  0.025    0.030    0.461 ## 5  1616  ~ 7133 -0.036 0.110 -0.324  0.746   -0.251    0.180 ## 6  4217  ~ 1616 -0.074 0.079 -0.943  0.346   -0.229    0.080 # ALS model fitting (sem1) # Common model and group influence on nodes (node perturbation)  sem1 <- SEMrun(graph = alsData$graph, data = data.npn, group = alsData$group) ## NLMINB solver ended normally after 6 iterations  ##  ## deviance/df: 11.02582  srmr: 0.274885  ##  ## Brown's combined P-value of node activation: 7.104523e-08  ##  ## Brown's combined P-value of node inhibition: 0.01068785 # verbose output #summary(sem1$fit) # short output head(parameterEstimates(sem1$fit)) ##     lhs op   rhs    est    se      z pvalue ci.lower ci.upper ## 1 10452  ~ group -0.150 0.078 -1.913  0.056   -0.303    0.004 ## 2  1432  ~ group -0.042 0.073 -0.578  0.563   -0.186    0.101 ## 3  1616  ~ group  0.025 0.080  0.314  0.754   -0.131    0.181 ## 4   317  ~ group  0.218 0.077  2.832  0.005    0.067    0.370 ## 5  4217  ~ group  0.176 0.078  2.273  0.023    0.024    0.328 ## 6  4741  ~ group  0.343 0.075  4.547  0.000    0.195    0.490 #Colored group effects on nodes and direct effects adjusted for group #(red/pink: activation, blue/lightblue: repression)  gplot(sem1$graph, main="Colored ALS graph") # ALS model fitting (sem2) # One model for each group and group influence on edges (edge perturbation)  sem2 <- SEMrun(alsData$graph, data.npn, alsData$group, fit = 2) ## Estimating optimal shrinkage intensity lambda (correlation matrix): 0.4313  ##  ## NLMINB solver ended normally after 7 iterations  ##  ## deviance/df: 16.08203  srmr: 0.2971455  ##  ## Brown's combined P-value of edge activation: 0.004597565  ##  ## Brown's combined P-value of edge inhibition: 0.9534567 # verbose output #summary(sem2$fit) # short output head(parameterEstimates(sem2$fit)) ##     lhs op  rhs    est    se      z pvalue ci.lower ci.upper group ## 1 10452  ~ 6647  0.198 0.214  0.928  0.353   -0.221    0.618     1 ## 2  1432  ~ 5606  0.101 0.209  0.482  0.630   -0.309    0.511     1 ## 3  1432  ~ 5608  0.346 0.209  1.654  0.098   -0.064    0.757     1 ## 4  1616  ~ 7132  0.120 0.240  0.499  0.618   -0.350    0.590     1 ## 5  1616  ~ 7133  0.118 0.240  0.493  0.622   -0.352    0.588     1 ## 6  4217  ~ 1616 -0.097 0.217 -0.445  0.656   -0.522    0.329     1 # Perturbed graph elements  # Differentially Regualted Nodes (DRNs) DRN <- sem1$gest[sem1$gest$pvalue < 0.05,] nrow(DRN) ## [1] 16 head(DRN) ##      lhs op   rhs   est    se     z pvalue ci.lower ci.upper ## 4    317  ~ group 0.218 0.077 2.832  0.005    0.067    0.370 ## 5   4217  ~ group 0.176 0.078 2.273  0.023    0.024    0.328 ## 6   4741  ~ group 0.343 0.075 4.547  0.000    0.195    0.490 ## 8   4747  ~ group 0.223 0.062 3.620  0.000    0.102    0.344 ## 9  54205  ~ group 0.188 0.069 2.730  0.006    0.053    0.322 ## 10  5530  ~ group 0.160 0.072 2.224  0.026    0.019    0.301 # Differentially Regulated Edges (DREs) DRE <- sem2$dest[sem2$dest$pvalue < 0.05,] nrow(DRE) ## [1] 3 head(DRE) ##     lhs op  rhs d_est  d_se   d_z pvalue d_lower d_upper ## 28 5532  ~ 6647 0.449 0.227 1.982  0.047   0.005   0.893 ## 30 5534  ~ 6647 0.584 0.229 2.546  0.011   0.135   1.034 ## 34 5603  ~ 5606 0.496 0.239 2.073  0.038   0.027   0.965 # Residual Iterative Conditional Fitting (RICF)  # Fast node perturbation fitting for large graphs (SE estimation disabled)  ricf1 <- SEMrun(alsData$graph, data.npn, alsData$group, algo = "ricf") ## RICF solver ended normally after 2 iterations  ##  ## deviance/df: 11.02558  srmr: 0.2747457  ##  ## Brown's combined P-value of node activation: 7.074471e-08  ##  ## Brown's combined P-value of node inhibition: 0.009522031 head(parameterEstimates(ricf1$fit)) ##   lhs op   rhs    est ## 1 317  ~ group  0.218 ## 2 572  ~ group -0.106 ## 3 581  ~ group -0.161 ## 4 596  ~ group  0.157 ## 5 598  ~ group  0.107 ## 6 836  ~ group  0.245 # Other possible output #summary(ricf1$fit) head(ricf1$gest) ##     Test    Stat tail       pvalue ## 317    t  2.8143   >< 0.0073759375 ## 572    t -1.3373   >< 0.1889142563 ## 581    t -2.0472   >< 0.0349464466 ## 596    t  2.0117   >< 0.0549088354 ## 598    t  1.3567   >< 0.1708148899 ## 836    t  3.6671   >< 0.0004791965 # Constrained Gaussian Graphical Modeling (CGGM) # Fast edge perturbation fitting for large graphs cggm2 <- SEMrun(alsData$graph, data.npn, alsData$group, fit = 2, algo = "cggm") ## GGM (de-biased nodewise L1) solver ended normally after 0 iterations  ##  ## deviance/df: 16.11538  srmr: 0.2977598  ##  ## Brown's combined P-value of edge activation: 8.441818e-05  ##  ## Brown's combined P-value of edge inhibition: 0.7365028 head(parameterEstimates(cggm2$fit)) ##     lhs op  rhs    est    se z_test pvalue ci.lower ci.uppper group ## 1 10452  ~ 6647  0.349 0.204  1.707  0.088   -0.052     0.750     1 ## 2 84134  ~ 6647  0.607 0.173  3.497  0.000    0.267     0.947     1 ## what: 2.3. Total effect estimation as Average Causal Effect (ACE).
title: Get started
text: Suppose path P = X -> M1 -> … -> Mk -> Y two nodes X Y, connected k mediators. total effect (TE = DE + IE) sum direct effect X -> Y, DE = b(X,Y), indirect effect mediators, IE = b(X,M1)*b(M1,M2)*…*b(Mk,Y). One convenient way estimating TE definition ACE Pearl J, 1998. simplest estimation TE ACE possible directed acyclic graphs (DAGs), thorugh linear regression. parent set pa(X) X blocks backdoor (.e., confounding) paths X Y, ACE equal coefficient b(X,Y) multiple regression Y ~ X + pa(X).
code: # Average Causal Effect (ACE) # optimal adjustement set (type = "optimal") # source -> sink ACE (effect = "source2sink") # Benjamini-Hochberg multiple test adjustment (method = "BH") # 5% significance level (alpha = 0.05)  ace <- SEMace(graph = alsData$graph, data = data.npn,               type = "optimal", effect = "source2sink",               method = "BH", alpha = 0.05) ##  ##  Frequency distribution of path length from X to Y : ##  1  2  3  4  5  ## 12  1  3  1  6  ##  ##  ACE= 1 of 23 ACE= 2 of 23 ACE= 3 of 23 ACE= 4 of 23 ACE= 5 of 23 ACE= 6 of 23 ACE= 7 of 23 ACE= 8 of 23 ACE= 9 of 23 ACE= 10 of 23 ACE= 11 of 23 ACE= 12 of 23 ACE= 13 of 23 ACE= 14 of 23 ACE= 15 of 23 ACE= 16 of 23 ACE= 17 of 23 ACE= 18 of 23 ACE= 19 of 23 ACE= 20 of 23 ACE= 21 of 23 ACE= 22 of 23 ACE= 23 of 23 # Sort by decreasing abs(z) value ace <- ace[order(abs(ace$z), decreasing = TRUE),] nrow(ace) ## [1] 10 head(ace) ##       pathL  sink op source    est    se      z pvalue ci.lower ci.upper ## 66471     1  4747 <-   6647  0.514 0.063  8.113      0    0.390    0.639 ## 317       2   836 <-    317  0.472 0.061  7.737      0    0.352    0.592 ## 11        1 79139 <-   6647  0.522 0.068  7.723      0    0.390    0.655 ## 13        1  5532 <-   6647  0.521 0.068  7.700      0    0.389    0.654 ## 16        1  5535 <-   6647 -0.462 0.070 -6.565      0   -0.600   -0.324 ## 6647      4   836 <-   6647  0.430 0.067  6.433      0    0.299    0.561 # SOD1-CASP3 path extraction and fitting  source <- as.character(ace$source[6]) sink <- as.character(ace$sink[6]) path <- SEMpath(alsData$graph, data.npn, alsData$group,                 from = source, to = sink,                 path = "directed",                 verbose = TRUE) ## Path: 6647 -> 836 size- 5 4 -- ##  ## NLMINB solver ended normally after 1 iterations  ##  ## deviance/df: 24.52913  srmr: 0.2068706  ##  ## Brown's combined P-value of node activation: 4.363726e-06  ##  ## Brown's combined P-value of node inhibition: 0.9267063 # Extract all directed paths, fit them, and evaluate their perturbation:  paths <- pathFinder(alsData$graph, data.npn, alsData$group, ace = ace) ##  ACE= 1 of 10 ACE= 2 of 10 ACE= 3 of 10 ACE= 4 of 10 ACE= 5 of 10 ACE= 6 of 10 ACE= 7 of 10 ACE= 8 of 10 ACE= 9 of 10 ACE= 10 of 10 ## Found 3 significant ACEs with > 2 nodes print(paths$dfp) ##   pathId sink op source n.nodes n.edges dev_df  srmr V.pv.act V.pv.inh ## 1   P317  836 <-    317       3       2 21.328 0.091 0.000042 0.232830 ## 2  P6647  836 <-   6647       5       4 24.526 0.207 0.000004 0.926706 ## 3   P581  836 <-    581       4       3  3.699 0.046 0.000959 0.179103

title: Get started
text: input graph picture current knowledge. Besides evaluation known relationships, data can used infer new ones. Four model search strategies implemented modelSearch function. basic one completely data-driven requires input graph establish initial topological order. direct strategy, input graph structure improved direct (.e., adjacent) link search, followed reference-based (“gnet” argument) interaction validation import reference network, mediators (d = 1). outer strategy, new interactions connectors (.e., mediators) searched imported reference network. strategy analogous “outer” one, disables external mediator search. words, new indirect paths generated adding new interactions nodes input model.    possible strategies:    Step 1-3 modelSearch() search=“outer” run following functions:
code: # Model Search with search = "basic" and beta = 0.1 # The beta argument determines the minimum absolute LASSO coefficient # for an edge to be included in the output model. # Reducing beta (up to 0) will increase model complexity.  # This strategy is data-driven (gnet = NULL) and  # only direct connections are added (d = 0; i.e., no new mediators), # these edges are colored in green  model <- modelSearch(graph = alsData$graph,                      data = data.npn,                      gnet = NULL, d = 0,                      search = "basic",                      beta = 0.1,                      method = "BH",                      alpha = 0.05,                      verbose = FALSE) ## Step1: BAP deconfounding... ## Step2: DAG estimation... ## Step3: DAG resize (remove edges/add nodes)... ##  ## None DAG resize for basic search !  ##  ## Done. # Convert Entrez identifiers to gene symbols V(model$graph)$label <- mapIds(org.Hs.eg.db, V(model$graph)$name,                               column = 'SYMBOL',                               keytype = 'ENTREZID') ## 'select()' returned 1:1 mapping between keys and columns #Colored plot: orange/cyan: sink/source nodes, green/gray: new/old edges gplot(model$graph, main="ALS model") # Node perturbation of the ALS model pert <- SEMrun(model$graph, model$data, alsData$group) ## NLMINB solver ended normally after 7 iterations  ##  ## deviance/df: 1.859277  srmr: 0.0818185  ##  ## Brown's combined P-value of node activation: 4.195065e-05  ##  ## Brown's combined P-value of node inhibition: 0.002192286 #Colored plot: red/pink: activation, blue/lightblue: repression gplot(pert$graph, main="ALS model") # SOD1-NEFM path extraction and fitting path <- SEMpath(pert$graph, model$data, alsData$group,                 from = "6647", #SOD1                 to = "4741", #NEFM                 path = "directed",                 verbose = TRUE) ## Path: 6647 -> 4741 size- 11 13 -- ##  ## NLMINB solver ended normally after 1 iterations  ##  ## deviance/df: 1.612045  srmr: 0.0658653  ##  ## Brown's combined P-value of node activation: 1.152006e-07  ##  ## Brown's combined P-value of node inhibition: 0.03466489 # Direct strategy. # - Knowledge-based estimation (gnet should be a directed reference network). # - Only direct interactions are inferred (d is fixed to 1). # - New interactions are inferred from data, during the execution. # - A smaller starting beta value is suggested (beta = 0.05)  model1 <- modelSearch(graph = alsData$graph,                       data = data.npn,                       gnet = kegg, d = 1,                       search = "direct",                       beta = 0.05,                       method = "BH",                       alpha = 0.05,                       verbose = FALSE) ## Step1: BAP deconfounding... ## Step2: DAG estimation... ## Step3: DAG resize (remove edges/add nodes)... ##  ## Done. # Inner strategy. # - The reference network is used to validate new interactions and mediators. # - Inferred mediators must already belong to the input graph. # - Larger d values increase model complexity (suggested: d = 2).  model2 <- modelSearch(graph = alsData$graph,                       data = data.npn,                       gnet = kegg, d = 2,                       search = "inner",                       beta = 0.05,                       method = "BH",                       alpha = 0.05,                       verbose = FALSE) ## Step1: BAP deconfounding... ## Step2: DAG estimation... ## Step3: DAG resize (remove edges/add nodes)... ##  ## Done. # Outer strategy. # - Knowledge-based estimation (gnet should be a directed reference network). # - Up to (d - 1) mediators can be imported from the reference network. # - Larger d values increase model complexity (suggested: d = 2).  model3 <- modelSearch(graph = alsData$graph,                       data = data.npn,                       gnet = kegg, d = 2,                       search = "outer",                       beta = 0.05,                       method = "BH",                       alpha = 0.05,                       verbose = FALSE) ## Step1: BAP deconfounding... ## Step2: DAG estimation... ## Step3: DAG resize (remove edges/add nodes)... ##  ## Done. # Outer strategy adds new nodes from kegg without node labels:  V(model3$graph)$label <- mapIds(org.Hs.eg.db, V(model3$graph)$name,                                 'SYMBOL', 'ENTREZID') ## 'select()' returned 1:1 mapping between keys and columns # graph models visualization: par(mfrow=c(2,2), mar=rep(2,4)) gplot(model$graph, main="basic") gplot(model1$graph, main="direct") gplot(model2$graph, main="inner") gplot(model3$graph, main="outer") # Step 1: Bow-free Acyclic Path (BAP) search.  BAP <- SEMbap(graph = alsData$graph,               data = data.npn,               method = "BH",                alpha = 0.05,               verbose = FALSE) ## Bow-free covariances search. Use method: cggm ... ## Number of bow-free covariances / df : 220 / 420  ## Max parent set(S) / Sparsity idx(s) : 10 / 4  ## Number of clusters / number of nodes: 2 / 31 # Step 2: Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) estimation.  DAG <- SEMdag(graph = alsData$graph,               data = BAP$data,               LO = "TO",               beta = 0.05,               lambdas = NA,               penalty = TRUE,               verbose = FALSE) ## Node Linear Ordering with TO setting # Step 3: Graph re-size with external interactome.  rsg <- resizeGraph(g = list(alsData$graph, DAG$dag.new),                    gnet = kegg,                    d = 2,                    v = TRUE,                    verbose = FALSE) ##  edge set= 1 of 17 edge set= 2 of 17 edge set= 3 of 17 edge set= 4 of 17 edge set= 5 of 17 edge set= 6 of 17 edge set= 7 of 17 edge set= 8 of 17 edge set= 9 of 17 edge set= 10 of 17 edge set= 11 of 17 edge set= 12 of 17 edge set= 13 of 17 edge set= 14 of 17 edge set= 15 of 17 edge set= 16 of 17 edge set= 17 of 17 ##  ##  n. edges to be evaluated: 17  ##  n. edges selected from interactome: 5 V(rsg)$label <- mapIds(org.Hs.eg.db, V(rsg)$name, 'SYMBOL', 'ENTREZID') ## 'select()' returned 1:1 mapping between keys and columns gplot(rsg)

title: Get started
text: modular structure biological networks often reveal local effects perturbed routes communities hidden within larger complex context. SEMgraph allows detect estimate local properties follows.
code: # Improved ALS model (model$graph) clustering and scoring, using a latent variable # "hidden" model (LV), edge betweeness clustering (EBC) algorithm, and a minimum  # cluster size of 5 nodes. # Other clustering algorithms can be exploited (e.g., the walktrap community  # detection algorithm, WTC) to improve the interpretation of results.  LV <- clusterScore(model$graph, model$data, alsData$group,                    type = "ebc",                    HM = "LV",                    size = 5) ## modularity = 0.4816345  ##  ## Community sizes ##  2  3  1  ##  6  9 10  ##  ## Model converged: TRUE  ## SRMR: 2.629474e-09 table(LV$membership) ##  ##  1  2  3  ## 10  6  9 head(parameterEstimates(LV$fit)) ##   lhs op   rhs    est    se      z pvalue ci.lower ci.upper ## 1 LV1  ~ group  0.043 0.249  0.171  0.864   -0.446    0.532 ## 2 LV2  ~ group -0.471 0.238 -1.975  0.048   -0.938   -0.004 ## 3 LV3  ~ group  0.744 0.287  2.588  0.010    0.181    1.307 ## 4 LV1 ~~   LV1  1.135 0.127  8.944  0.000    0.887    1.384 ## 5 LV2 ~~   LV2  1.037 0.116  8.944  0.000    0.809    1.264 ## 6 LV3 ~~   LV3  1.506 0.168  8.944  0.000    1.176    1.836 # Clustering only (no scores calculation)  C <- clusterGraph(model$graph, type = "ebc", HM = "LV", size = 5) ## modularity = 0.4816345  ##  ## Community sizes ##  2  3  1  ##  6  9 10 # Cluster plot utility  cg <- cplot(graph = model$graph, membership = LV$membership, verbose = TRUE) list(cg) ## [[1]] ## [[1]]$graph ## IGRAPH 87f1ee5 DN-- 25 33 --  ## + attr: name (v/c), color (v/n), label (v/c), M (v/n), color (e/c) ## + edges from 87f1ee5 (vertex names): ##  [1] 1432 ->4744  1432 ->4741  5600 ->4744  5600 ->4741  6300 ->4744  ##  [6] 6300 ->4741  5532 ->4744  5603 ->4741  5603 ->4747  6647 ->84134 ## [11] 6647 ->596   6647 ->4747  6647 ->5535  6647 ->5533  6647 ->79139 ## [16] 54205->5603  54205->842   5606 ->1432  5606 ->5603  5608 ->1432  ## [21] 5608 ->5600  10452->1432  84134->5608  4217 ->5608  572  ->54205 ## [26] 572  ->4217  7133 ->4217  7133 ->1616  1616 ->4217  581  ->54205 ## [31] 596  ->54205 596  ->1616  598  ->54205 ##  ## [[1]]$HM1 ## IGRAPH 89acadd DN-- 10 13 --  ## + attr: name (v/c), color (v/n), label (v/c), M (v/n), color (e/c) ## + edges from 89acadd (vertex names): ##  [1] 1432 ->4744 1432 ->4741 5600 ->4744 5600 ->4741 6300 ->4744 6300 ->4741 ##  [7] 5532 ->4744 5603 ->4741 5606 ->1432 5606 ->5603 5608 ->1432 5608 ->5600 ## [13] 10452->1432 ##  ## [[1]]$HM2 ## IGRAPH 89acb77 DN-- 6 5 --  ## + attr: name (v/c), color (v/n), label (v/c), M (v/n), color (e/c) ## + edges from 89acb77 (vertex names): ## [1] 6647->84134 6647->4747  6647->5535  6647->5533  6647->79139 ##  ## [[1]]$HM3 ## IGRAPH 89acbe4 DN-- 9 10 --  ## + attr: name (v/c), color (v/n), label (v/c), M (v/n), color (e/c) ## + edges from 89acbe4 (vertex names): ##  [1] 54205->842   572  ->54205 572  ->4217  7133 ->4217  7133 ->1616  ##  [6] 1616 ->4217  581  ->54205 596  ->54205 596  ->1616  598  ->54205 # Colored cluster plot:   #Set label and node colors V(cg$graph)$label <- mapIds(org.Hs.eg.db, V(cg$graph)$name,                             column = 'SYMBOL',                             keytype = 'ENTREZID') ## 'select()' returned 1:1 mapping between keys and columns V(cg$graph)$color[V(cg$graph)$color == 2] <- "lightsalmon" V(cg$graph)$color[V(cg$graph)$color == 3] <- "lightgreen" V(cg$graph)$color[V(cg$graph)$color == 4] <- "lightyellow"  gplot(cg$graph) # Cluster extraction, fitting, and perturbation evaluation  cls <- extractClusters(graph = model$graph,                        data = model$data,                        group = alsData$group,                        membership = LV$membership) ##  cluster= 1 of 3 cluster= 2 of 3 cluster= 3 of 3 ##  ##  ## Found 3 clusters with > 5 nodes print(cls$dfc) ##   cluster n.nodes n.edges dev_df  srmr V.pv.act V.pv.inh ## 1     HM1      10      13  2.283 0.068 0.000000 0.014398 ## 2     HM2       6       5  1.895 0.056 0.926485 0.052001 ## 3     HM3       9      10  1.917 0.077 0.122245 0.126563

title: Get started
text: FTD dataset coming SEMdata data matrix 256 rows (subjects; 150 FTD patients 150 healthy controls) 16560 columns (genes) containing value first principal component DNAme levels, obtained applying principal component analysis methylated CpG sites within promoter region, gene (genes unmethylated CpGs conditions discarded). dataset derived study Li Y. et al., 2014 (GEO accession: GSE53740).

title: Get started
text: absence conceptual model (.e., one built expert’s indication), input graph can inferred data, literature . following example, take advantage FTD dataset known FTD-associated pathways KEGG database. end, GSA can used assess actual perturbation known pathways, given data, extract genes (.e., seeds) underlying perturbed routes. Seeds can also defined using knowledge, importing list known disease-associated genes, data sources (e.g. mutational, transcriptional, epigenetic data).
code: #load KEGG pathways kegg.pathways <- SEMgraph::kegg.pathways length(kegg.pathways) #225 ## [1] 225 head(names(kegg.pathways)) ## [1] "EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor resistance" ## [2] "Endocrine resistance"                      ## [3] "Antifolate resistance"                     ## [4] "Platinum drug resistance"                  ## [5] "mRNA surveillance pathway"                 ## [6] "RNA degradation" # Known FTD-related pathway selection  ftd.pathways <- c("MAPK signaling pathway",                   "Protein processing in endoplasmic reticulum",                   "Endocytosis",                   "Wnt signaling pathway",                   "Notch signaling pathway",                   "Neurotrophin signaling pathway")  # Pathway extraction  j <- which(names(kegg.pathways) %in% ftd.pathways)  # Gene set analysis (GSA) with 5000 permutations  ftd.gsa <- SEMgsa(kegg.pathways[j], pc1.npn, group, n_rep = 5000) ## k = 1 MAPK signaling pathway  ## k = 2 Protein processing in endoplasmic reticulum  ## k = 3 Endocytosis  ## k = 4 Wnt signaling pathway  ## k = 5 Notch signaling pathway  ## k = 6 Neurotrophin signaling pathway print(ftd.gsa$gsa) ## Endocytosis                                 1.468533e-08 1.193403e-05 ## Neurotrophin signaling pathway              4.480197e-06 2.574927e-02 ## Wnt signaling pathway                       5.376131e-06 3.229422e-02 ## Wnt signaling pathway                       1.075226e-05 6.451357e-05 ## MAPK signaling pathway                      3.268743e-05 1.961246e-04 ## Notch signaling pathway                     3.332071e-04 1.999242e-03 # Seed extraction  seed <- unique(unlist(ftd.gsa$DEG)) length(seed) #60 ## what: 3.2. Network weighting and perturbed backbone extraction.
title: Get started
text: seeds pinpoint nodes specific properties, edges can weighted base quantitative phenotype data define preferential ways information exchange (e.g., perturbation propagation) network. SEMgraph offers different alternatives generate data-driven weights, fastest based Fisher’s “r--z” method, test group difference correlation coefficients pairs interacting nodes (Fisher, 1915). seeds weights can used extract perturbed core(s) network highlight disease-associated components.
code: # KEGG interactome weighting  #load KEGG interactome kegg<- SEMgraph::kegg summary(kegg) #DNW- 5007 44755 ## IGRAPH b46d4ee DNW- 5007 44755 --  ## + attr: name (v/c), weight (e/n) W <- weightGraph(kegg, pc1.npn, group, method = "r2z") summary(W) #DNW- 4242 34975 ## IGRAPH 9aa7cef DNW- 4242 34975 --  ## + attr: name (v/c), pv (v/n), zsign (v/n), weight (e/n), zsign (e/n), ## | pv (e/n) # Perturbed backbone as a Steiner tree (Kou's algorithm) # A Steiner tree is the minimum cost (distance) graph # including all the specified seeds.  ST <- SEMtree(W, data = pc1.npn, seed = seed, type = "ST", eweight = "pvalue") summary(ST) #DNW- 92 (90 directed + 1 bidirected) ## IGRAPH 9bf5bc9 DNW- 92 92 --  ## + attr: pv (v/n), zsign (v/n), name (v/c), color (v/c), weight (e/n), ## | color (e/c), width (e/n) # Colored plot: green, seed nodes; white, connection nodes gplot(ST, l="fdp") # Perturbation evaluation with raw data  sem1 <- SEMrun(ST, pc1.npn, group) ## NLMINB solver ended normally after 15 iterations  ##  ## deviance/df: 5.894448  srmr: 0.4100293  ##  ## Brown's combined P-value of node activation: 0.000430902  ##  ## Brown's combined P-value of node inhibition: 3.476108e-13 # Data deconfounding and perturbation evaluation  # When a DAG is used for causal network inference, missing edges  # are often masked by unmeasured confounding variables. # This step might reduce this effect through Bow-free Acyclic Path (BAP)  # search and data deconfounding.  adj.pc1 <- SEMbap(ST, pc1.npn, method = "bonferroni", alpha = 5E-06) ## DAG conversion : TRUE ## Bow-free covariances search. Use method: cggm ... ## Number of bow-free covariances / df : 1208 / 4096  ## Max parent set(S) / Sparsity idx(s) : 9 / 4  ## Number of clusters / number of nodes: 2 / 85 adj.sem1 <- SEMrun(ST, adj.pc1$data, group) ## NLMINB solver ended normally after 8 iterations  ##  ## deviance/df: 1.614218  srmr: 0.0736439  ##  ## Brown's combined P-value of node activation: 0.03622072  ##  ## Brown's combined P-value of node inhibition: 0.01004111 #Colored plot: red/pink: activation, blue/lightblue: repression gplot(adj.sem1$graph, l="fdp") # Tree agglomerative hierarchical clustering (TAHC). # This allow us to detect possible communities within our Steiner tree.  C <- clusterGraph(ST, type = "tahc") cg <- cplot(ST, membership=C) summary(cg) ##       Length Class  Mode ## graph 92     igraph list ## HM1   25     igraph list ## HM2   32     igraph list ## HM3   22     igraph list ## HM4   13     igraph list #Colored plot: set 2nd cluster (HM2), node color and size cg2 <- cg$HM2 V(cg2)$color <- ifelse(V(cg2)$name %in% seed, "green", "white") V(cg2)$size <- 3*degree(cg2, mode="total")  # Convert Entrez identifiers to gene symbols V(cg2)$label <- mapIds(org.Hs.eg.db, V(cg2)$name, 'SYMBOL', 'ENTREZID') ## 'select()' returned 1:1 mapping between keys and columns # Plot cluster (green nodes are seed nodes) gplot(cg2, l = "neato")

title: Get started
text: SEMgraph differential connected inference (DCI) module enables detection perturbed nodes edges large graphs. module useful aim find perturbed backbone essential disease-associated nodes nodes.  Note: global statistics suggest poor fit, de-correlation performed; however, significant perturbation two conditions observed, shown extracted subgraph pink (beta > 0: activation) light blue (beta < 0: repression) nodes, red (delta > 0: activation) blue (delta < 0: repression) edges, respectively.
code: # Input graph as the union of FTD KEGG pathways  gU <- Reduce(igraph::union, kegg.pathways[j]) gU <- properties(gU)[[1]] ## Frequency distribution of graph components ##  ##   n.nodes n.graphs ## 1       3        2 ## 2       4        1 ## 3       7        2 ## 4       8        1 ## 5      10        2 ## 6      12        2 ## 7     586        1 ##  ## Percent of vertices in the giant component: 63.8 % ##  ##   is.simple      is.dag is.directed is.weighted  ##        TRUE       FALSE        TRUE       FALSE  ##  ## which.mutual.FALSE  which.mutual.TRUE  ##               3564                  8 summary(gU) #DNW- 586 3572 ## IGRAPH a607d02 DN-- 586 3572 --  ## + attr: name (v/c) # DCI with the WTC clustering algorithm  gD <- SEMdci(gU, pc1.npn, group, type = "wtc", method = "BH", alpha = 0.05) ## modularity = 0.6539108  ##  ## Community sizes ##  14  17  20  25  18  22  21  11   8   4  13  23  10  16  12  15   9  19  24  26  ##   2   2   2   2   3   3   4   5   6   7   7   7   8   8   9  13  15  15  25  26  ##   6   1   3   2   5   7  ##  27  47  68  71  86 118  ##  ## fit cluster = 1  ## fit cluster = 2  ## fit cluster = 3  ## fit cluster = 5  ## fit cluster = 6  ## fit cluster = 7  ## fit cluster = 9  ## fit cluster = 15  ## fit cluster = 19  ## fit cluster = 24  ## fit cluster = 26  ## Done. summary(gD) #DN-- 74 61 ## IGRAPH a8a5cbd DN-- 74 61 --  ## + attr: name (v/c) # Perturbation evaluation of the 1st component of gD  gC1 <- properties(gD)[[1]] ## Frequency distribution of graph components ##  ##   n.nodes n.graphs ## 1       2        7 ## 2       3        5 ## 3       5        1 ## 4      14        1 ## 5      26        1 ##  ## Percent of vertices in the giant component: 35.1 % ##  ##   is.simple      is.dag is.directed is.weighted  ##        TRUE        TRUE        TRUE       FALSE  ##  ## which.mutual.FALSE  ##                 27 sem1 <- SEMrun(gC1, pc1.npn, group) ## NLMINB solver ended normally after 6 iterations  ##  ## deviance/df: 12.68914  srmr: 0.3918051  ##  ## Brown's combined P-value of node activation: 0.2123603  ##  ## Brown's combined P-value of node inhibition: 4.865384e-05 sem2 <- SEMrun(sem1$graph, pc1.npn, group, fit = 2) ## NLMINB solver ended normally after 2 iterations  ##  ## deviance/df: 5.099692  srmr: 0.1504874  ##  ## Brown's combined P-value of edge activation: 0.01959594  ##  ## Brown's combined P-value of edge inhibition: 9.001465e-06 # Colored DCI plot gC1 <- sem2$graph  # Convert Entrez identifiers to gene symbols V(gC1)$label <- mapIds(org.Hs.eg.db, V(gC1)$name, "SYMBOL", "ENTREZID") ## 'select()' returned 1:1 mapping between keys and columns # Set node size V(gC1)$size <- 1.5*degree(gC1, mode="total")  gplot(gC1, l="neato")

title: SEMgraph
text: SEMgraph estimates networks causal relations complex systems Structural Equation Modeling (SEM). SEMgraph runs directed graph (adjacency matrix) encodes hypothesized data-driven causal links among variables. comes following functionalities: Interchangeable model representation either igraph object corresponding SEM lavaan syntax. Model management functions include graph--SEM conversion, automated covariance matrix regularization, graph conversion DAG, tree (arborescence) correlation matrices. Heuristic filtering, node edge weighting, resampling parallelization settings fast fitting case large models. Automated data-driven model building improvement, causal structure learning bow-free interaction search latent variable confounding adjustment. Perturbed paths finding, community searching sample scoring, together graph plotting utilities, tracing model architecture modifications perturbation (.e., activation repression) routes.

title: Topological graph clustering — clusterGraph
text: graph igraph object. type Topological clustering methods. type = "tahc", network modules generated using tree agglomerative hierarchical clustering method (Yu et al., 2015). non-tree clustering methods igraph package include: "wtc" (default value; walktrap community structure short random walks), "ebc" (edge betweeness clustering), "fgc" (fast greedy method), "lbc" (label propagation method), "lec" (leading eigenvector method), "loc" (multi-level optimization), "opc" (optimal community structure), "sgc" (spinglass statistical mechanics). HM Hidden model type. Enables visualization hidden model, gHM. set "none" (default), gHM igraph object saved. defined hidden module: () HM = "LV", latent variable (LV) defined common unknown cause acting cluster nodes; (ii) HM = "CV", cluster nodes considered regressors latent composite variable (CV); (iii) HM = "UV", unmeasured variable (UV) defined, source nodes module (.e., -degree = 0) act common regressors influencing nodes via unmeasured variable (see also clusterScore). size Minimum number nodes per module. default, minimum number 5 nodes required. verbose logical value. FALSE (default), gHM igraph plotted screen, saving execution time (returned output anyway). ... Currently ignored.

code: # \donttest{ # Model fitting: node perturbation sem1 <- SEMrun(graph = alsData$graph, data = alsData$exprs,                group = alsData$group,                fit = 1) #> NLMINB solver ended normally after 1 iterations  #>  #> deviance/df: 12.66492  srmr: 0.303644  #>  #> Brown's combined P-value of node activation: 8.943957e-13  #>  #> Brown's combined P-value of node inhibition: 0.02173378  #>  est1 <- parameterEstimates(sem1$fit)  # Model fitting: edge perturbation sem2 <- SEMrun(graph = alsData$graph, data = alsData$exprs,                group = alsData$group,                fit = 2) #> Estimating optimal shrinkage intensity lambda (correlation matrix): 0.4547  #>  #> NLMINB solver ended normally after 7 iterations  #>  #> deviance/df: 16.91727  srmr: 0.3247998  #>  #> Brown's combined P-value of edge activation: 0.01363458  #>  #> Brown's combined P-value of edge inhibition: 0.8656962  #>  est20 <- subset(parameterEstimates(sem2$fit), group == 1)[, -c(4, 5)] est21 <- subset(parameterEstimates(sem2$fit), group == 2)[, -c(4, 5)]  # Graphs g <- alsData$graph x <- alsData$group  old.par <- par(no.readonly = TRUE) par(mfrow=c(2,2), mar=rep(1,4)) gplot(colorGraph(est = est1, g, group = x, method = "BH"),       main = "vertex differences") gplot(colorGraph(est = sem2$dest, g, group = NULL),       main = "edge differences") gplot(colorGraph(est = est20, g, group = NULL),       main = "edges for group = 0") gplot(colorGraph(est = est21, g, group = NULL),       main = "edges for group = 1")  par(old.par) # }

Use method: cggm ... #> Number of bow-free covariances / df : 220 / 420  #> Max parent set(S) / Sparsity idx(s) : 10 / 4  #> Number of clusters / number of nodes: 2 / 31  #>   # Clusters creation clusters <- extractClusters(alsData$graph, adjdata, alsData$group) #> modularity = 0.5588502  #>  #> Community sizes #>  3  2  1  4  #>  4  8  9 11  #>  #>   cluster= 1 of 3  cluster= 2 of 3  cluster= 3 of 3 #>  #>  #> Found 3 clusters with > 5 nodes print(clusters$dfc) #>   cluster n.nodes n.edges dev_df  srmr V.pv.act V.pv.inh #> 1     HM1       9       8  1.062 0.052 0.000118 0.058611 #> 2     HM2       8       7  1.180 0.059 0.000468 0.927939 #> 3     HM4      11      25  1.840 0.059 0.000002 0.007126 head(parameterEstimates(clusters$fit$HM1)) #>     lhs op   rhs    est #> 1  6647  ~ group -0.156 #> 2 10452  ~ group -0.021 #> 3 84134  ~ group -0.080 #> 4 79139  ~ group  0.000 #> 5  5530  ~ group -0.134 #> 6  5532  ~ group  0.169 head(parameterEstimates(clusters$fit$HM2)) #>     lhs op   rhs    est #> 1 54205  ~ group  0.056 #> 2   836  ~ group  0.200 #> 3   581  ~ group -0.013 #> 4   572  ~ group -0.045 #> 5   596  ~ group  0.127 #> 6   598  ~ group  0.198 head(parameterEstimates(clusters$fit$HM4)) #>    lhs op   rhs    est #> 1 4217  ~ group  0.086 #> 2 5606  ~ group  0.033 #> 3 5608  ~ group  0.188 #> 4 1432  ~ group -0.017 #> 5 5600  ~ group -0.296 #> 6 5603  ~ group  0.003 gplot(clusters$clusters$HM2)   # Map cluster on the input graph g <- alsData$graph c <- clusters$clusters$HM2 V(g)$color <- ifelse(V(g)$name %in% V(c)$name, "gold", "white") gplot(g)  # }

title: Factor analysis for high dimensional data — factor.analysis
text: two methods extracted "cate" quasi-maximum likelihood (ml), principal component analysis (pc). ml iteratively solved EM algorithm using PCA solution initial value. See Bai Li (2012) details.

title: Graph plotting with renderGraph — gplot
text: graph igraph graphNEL object. l layout supported Rgraphviz. can one among: "dot" (default), "neato", "circo", "fdp", "osage", "twopi". main Plot main title (default, title added). cex.main Main title size (default = 1). font.main Main title font (default = 1). Available options : 1 plain text, 2 bold, 3 italics, 4 bold italics, 5 symbol. color.txt Node text color (default = "black"). fontsize Node text size (default = 16). cex Another argument control node text size (default = 0.6). shape Node shape (default = "circle"). color Node border color (default = "gray70"). lty Node border outline (default = 1). Available options include: 0 blank, 1 solid line, 2 dashed, 3 dotted, 4 dotdash, 5 longdash, 6 twodash. lwd Node border thickness (default = 1). w Manual node width (default = "auto"). h Manual node height (default = "auto"). psize Automatic node size (default = 80). ... Currently ignored.

what: Conditional Independence (CI) local tests of an acyclic graph — localCI.test
title: Conditional Independence (CI) local tests of an acyclic graph — localCI.test
text: P-values one minimal testable implication (smallest possible conditioning set) returned per missing edge given acyclic graph (DAG BAP) using function impliedConditionalIndependencies plus function localTests package dagitty. Without assuming particular dependence structure, p-values every CI test, DAG (BAP), combined using Bonferroni’s statistic overall test fitted model, B = K*min(p1,...,pK), reviewed Vovk & Wang (2020).

title: Conditional Independence (CI) local tests of an acyclic graph — localCI.test
code: localCI.test(graph, data, bap = FALSE, limit = 100, verbose = TRUE, ...)

title: Conditional Independence (CI) local tests of an acyclic graph — localCI.test
text: graph directed graph igraph object. data data matrix subjects rows variables columns. bap TRUE, input graph trasformend BAP, FALSE (defult) input graph reduced DAG. limit integer value corresponding size extracted acyclic graph. Beyond limit, switch Shipley's C-test (Shipley 2000) enabled reduce computational burden. default, limit = 100. verbose TRUE, LocalCI results showed screen (default = TRUE). ... Currently ignored.

title: Conditional Independence (CI) local tests of an acyclic graph — localCI.test
text: list three objects: () "dag": DAG used perform localCI test (ii) "msep": list m-separation tests missing edges input graph (iii) "mtest":overall Bonferroni's P-value.

title: Conditional Independence (CI) local tests of an acyclic graph — localCI.test
text: Vovk V, Wang R (2020). Combining p-values via averaging. Biometrika 107(4): 791-808. <https://doi.org/10.1093/biomet/asaa027> Shipley B (2000). new inferential test path models based DAGs. Structural Equation Modeling, 7(2): 206-218. <https://doi.org/10.1207/S15328007SEM0702_4>

code: mergeNodes(   graph,   data,   h = 0.5,   membership = NULL,   HM = NULL,   verbose = FALSE,   ... )

title: Graph nodes merging by a membership attribute — mergeNodes
text: graph network igraph object. data matrix data.frame. Rows correspond subjects, columns graph nodes. membership NULL, currently ignored, data = NULL. h Cutting minimax clustering height, h = 1 - abs(cor(j,k)), yielding merged node (reduced data set) every node cluster correlation least cor(j,k) prototype node. default, h = 0.5, .e. cor(j,k) = 0.5. membership Cluster membership. vector cluster membership identifiers numeric values, vector names correspond graph node names. default, membership = NULL. HM Hidden cluster label. membership derived clusterGraph: HM = "LV", latent variable (LV) defined common unknown cause acting cluster nodes. HM = "CV", cluster nodes considered regressors latent composite variable (CV). Finally, HM = "UV", unmeasured variable (UV) defined, source nodes module (.e., -degree = 0) act common regressors influencing nodes via unmeasured variable. default, HM = NULL verbose logical value. FALSE (default), merged graphs plotted screen. ... Currently ignored.

title: Graph nodes merging by a membership attribute — mergeNodes
text: list 2 objects returned: "gLM", graph merged nodes igraph object; "membership", cluster membership vector node.

title: Graph nodes merging by a membership attribute — mergeNodes
text: Hierarchical clustering prototypes (Minmax linkage) unique naturally associating node (prototypes) every interior node dendogram. Thus, merge single representative data point resulting cluster (Bien, Tibshirani, 2011). prototypes can used greatly enhance interpretability merging nodes data reduction SEM fitting.

title: Graph nodes merging by a membership attribute — mergeNodes
code: # Gene memberships with prototypes with h=0.5 G <- properties(alsData$graph)[[1]] #> Frequency distribution of graph components #>  #>   n.nodes n.graphs #> 1      32        1 #>  #> Percent of vertices in the giant component: 100 % #>  #>   is.simple      is.dag is.directed is.weighted  #>        TRUE        TRUE        TRUE        TRUE  #>  #> which.mutual.FALSE  #>                 47  M <- mergeNodes(G, data = alsData$exprs, h = 0.5, verbose=TRUE)    # Gene memberships with EBC method and size=10 m <- clusterGraph(G, type = "ebc", size = 10) #> modularity = 0.5588502  #>  #> Community sizes #>  3  2  1  4  #>  4  8  9 11  #>  M <- mergeNodes(G, membership = m, HM = "LV", verbose=TRUE)   # Gene memberships defined by user c1 <- c("5894", "5576", "5567", "572", "598") c2 <- c("6788", "84152", "2915", "836", "5530") c3 <- c("5603", "6300", "1432", "5600") m <- c(rep(1,5), rep(2,5), rep(3,4)) names(m) <- c(c1, c2, c3) M <- mergeNodes(G, membership = m, HM = "CV", verbose=TRUE)

title: Optimal model search strategies — modelSearch
text: Four model search strategies implemented combining SEMdag(), SEMbap(), resizeGraph() functions. strategies estimate new graph 1) adjusting (BAP deconfounding) data matrix 2) re-sizing output DAG.

title: Optimal model search strategies — modelSearch
code: modelSearch(   graph,   data,   gnet = NULL,   d = 2,   search = "basic",   beta = 0,   method = "BH",   alpha = 0.05,   verbose = FALSE,   ... )

title: Optimal model search strategies — modelSearch
text: graph Input graph igraph object. data matrix data.frame. Rows correspond subjects, columns graph nodes (variables). gnet Reference directed network used validate import nodes interactions. d Maximum allowed geodesic distance directed undirected shortest path search. distance d = 0 disables shortest path search (fixed search = "basic"), d = 1 (fixed search = "direct") search directed links (.e., mediators allowed). distance d > 1 (defaults d = 2 "outer" "inner" strategies), search shortest paths d - 1 mediators nodes sharing significant estimated interaction. Connectors imported reference interactome, specified argument gnet. edges reference interactome weighted P-value, defined E(gnet)$pv attribute, shortest path smallest sum weights chosen (e.g., see weightGraph graph weighting options). search Search strategy. Four model search strategies available: "outer". estimated DAG re-sized using resizeGraph find new indirect paths (.e., inferred directed connections may hide new mediators). New interactions connectors searched imported reference network (argument gnet, see ). DAG extended graph complexity can controlled beta > 0 d > 1 arguments, respectively. term "outer" means new model mediator variables imported external resource (.e., reference network). "inner". strategy analogous "outer" one, disables external mediator search. words, new indirect paths generated adding new interactions input model, mediators nodes already present input graph. reference network still used validate new model paths. Also case, beta > 0 d > 1 used. "direct". input graph structure improved direct (.e., adjacent) link search, followed interaction validation import reference network, mediators (.e., d = 1). "basic" (default). previous strategies rely input graph reference network integrate knowledge final model, "basic" strategy data-driven. input graph needed define topological order. argument gnet set NULL (.e., reference network needed) argument d = 0. Model complexity can still controlled setting beta > 0. beta Numeric value. Minimum absolute LASSO beta coefficient new interaction retained estimated DAG backbone. Lower beta values correspond complex DAGs. default, beta set 0 (.e., maximum complexity). method Multiple testing correction method. One values available p.adjust. default, method set "BH" (.e., Benjamini-Hochberg multiple test correction). alpha Significance level false discovery rate (FDR) used local d-separation tests. argument used control data de-correlation. higher alpha level includes hidden covariances, thus considering sources confounding. alpha = 0, data de-correlation disabled. default, alpha = 0.05. verbose TRUE, shows intermediate graphs execution (recommended large graphs). ... Currently ignored.

title: Optimal model search strategies — modelSearch
text: output model well adjusted dataset returned list 2 objects: "graph", output model igraph object; "data", adjusted dataset.

title: Optimal model search strategies — modelSearch
text: Search strategies can ordered decreasing conservativeness respect input graph, : "direct", "inner", "outer", "basic". first three strategies knowledge-based, since require input graph reference network, together data, knowledge-assisted model improvement. last one require reference output model structure data-driven. Output model complexity can limited using arguments d beta. d fixed 0 1 "basic" "direct", respectively; suggest starting d = 2 (one mediator) two strategies. knowledge-based strategies, suggest start beta = 0. , beta can relaxed (0 < 0.1) improve model fitting, needed. Since data-driven models can complex, suggest start beta = 0 using "basic" strategy. beta value can relaxed good model fit obtained. Argument alpha determines extent data adjustment: lower alpha values FDR correction correspond smaller number significant confounding factors, hence weaker correction (default alpha = 0.05).

title: Optimal model search strategies — modelSearch
text: Mario Grassi mario.grassi@unipv.

title: Optimal model search strategies — modelSearch
code: # \donttest{ # Comparison among different model estimation strategies  # Nonparanormal(npn) transformation als.npn <- transformData(alsData$exprs)$data #> Conducting the nonparanormal transformation via shrunkun ECDF...done. # Reference network (KEGG interactome) gnet <- kegg  # Models estimation m1 <- modelSearch(graph = alsData$graph, data = als.npn, gnet = gnet,       search = "direct", beta = 0, alpha = 0.05) #> Step1: BAP deconfounding... #> Step2: DAG estimation... #> Step3: DAG resize (remove edges/add nodes)... #>  #> Done. m2 <- modelSearch(graph = alsData$graph, data = als.npn, gnet = gnet,       d = 2, search = "inner", beta = 0, alpha = 0.05) #> Step1: BAP deconfounding... #> Step2: DAG estimation... #> Step3: DAG resize (remove edges/add nodes)... #>  #> Done. m3 <- modelSearch(graph = alsData$graph, data = als.npn, gnet = gnet,       d = 2, search = "outer", beta = 0, alpha = 0.05) #> Step1: BAP deconfounding... #> Step2: DAG estimation... #> Step3: DAG resize (remove edges/add nodes)... #>  #> Done. m4 <- modelSearch(graph = alsData$graph, data = als.npn, gnet = NULL,       search = "basic", beta = 0.1, alpha = 0.05) #> Step1: BAP deconfounding... #> Step2: DAG estimation... #> Step3: DAG resize (remove edges/add nodes)... #>  #> None DAG resize for basic search !  #>  #> Done.  # Graphs #old.par <- par(no.readonly = TRUE) #par(mfrow=c(2,2), mar= rep(1,4)) gplot(m1$graph, main = "direct graph")  gplot(m2$graph, main = "inner graph")  gplot(m3$graph, main = "outer graph")  gplot(m4$graph, main = "basic graph")  #par(old.par) # }

title: Bow-free covariance search and data de-correlation — SEMbap
text: graph igraph object. data matrix whith rows corresponding subjects, columns graph nodes (variables). group binary vector. vector must long number subjects. vector element must 1 cases 0 control subjects. NULL (default), confouding within group considered. dalgo Deconfounding method. Four algorithms available: "cggm" (default). algorithm make: () exhaustive search bow-free significant covariances (see details) Shipley.test function; (ii) estimation inverse selected covariance matrix (.e. precision matrix, W) fitConGraph function; (iii) obtain de-correlated data matrix, Z multiplying data matrix, Y rightward square root estimated precision matrix, Z=YW^(1/2) suggested Grassi, Palluzzi Tarantino (2022). "glpc". algorithm first makes exhaustive search bow-free significant covariances Shipley.test function. obtained adjacency matrix, Graph-Laplacian PCA (gLPCA) algorithm (Jiang et al., 2013) learns low dimensional representation observed data matrix incorporates bow-free structure. , DAG extended including confounding proxies, .e. LVs, additional source nodes defined last q principal component scores gLPCA LV scores added data matrix, Z=cbind(LV,Y). "pc". procedure add additional source nodes DAG "glpc" algorithm, confounding proxies q principal component scores extracted Spectral decomposition (SVD) selecting graph nodes without graph edge information bow-free covariance search. "trim". Ćevid et al. (2020) suggest multiplying data matrix, Y leftward well selected spectrum transformation matrix, T modifies singular values Y, keeping singular vectors intact, Z=TY. Trim transform limits singular values costant (t), t = median singuar values. method Multiple testing correction method. One values available p.adjust. default, method set "BH" (.e., Benjamini-Hochberg multiple test correction). alpha Significance level false discovery rate (FDR) used d-separation test. argument used control data de-correlation. higher alpha level includes hidden covariances, thus considering sources confounding. alpha = 0, data de-correlation disabled. default, alpha = 0.05. hcount number latent (hidden) variables. default hcount="auto", hidden count determined permutation method (see details). Currently ignored (dalgo ="cggm" "trim"). cmax Maximum number parents set, C. parameter can used perform tests number conditioning variables exceed given value. High-dimensional conditional independence tests can unreliable. default, cmax = Inf. limit integer value corresponding graph size (vcount) tolerance. Beyond limit, precision matrix estimated "glasso" algorithm (FHT, 2008) reduce computational burden exaustive BAP search Shipley.test procedure. default, limit = 200. verbose logical value. FALSE (default), processed graphs plotted screen. ... Currently ignored.

title: Bow-free covariance search and data de-correlation — SEMbap
text: list four objects: "dag", directed acyclic graph (DAG) extracted input graph. (dalgo = "glpc" "pc"), DAG also includes LVs source nodes. "guu", bow-free covariance graph, BAP = dag + guu. (dalgo = "pc" "trim"), guu equal NULL "adj", adjacency matrix selected bow-free covariances; .e, missing edges selected multiple testing correction. (dalgo = "pc" "trim"), adj matrix equal NULL. "data", adjusted (de-correlated) data matrix (dalgo = "glpc", "pc"), combined data matrix, first columns represent LVs scores columns raw data.

title: Bow-free covariance search and data de-correlation — SEMbap
text: Missing edges causal network inference using directed acyclic graph (DAG) frequently hidden unmeasured confounding variables. Bow-free Acyclic Paths (BAP) search performed d-separation tests pairs variables missing connection input DAG, adding bidirected edge (.e., bow-free covariance) DAG association . d-separation test evaluates two variables (Y1, Y2) DAG conditionally independent given conditioning set, C represented DAG union parent sets Y1 Y2 (Shipley, 2000). new bow-free covariance added significant (Y1, Y2) association significance level alpha, multiple testing correction. selected covariance pairs nodes interpreted effect latent variable (LV) acting nodes; .e., LV unobserved confounder. BAP-based algorithms adjust (de-correlate) observed data matrix conditioning latent triggers responsible nuisance edges. "pc" algorithm number hidden proxies, q determined permutation method. compares singular values variables independent, estimated permuting columns data matrix, Y selects components singular values larger permuted data (review see Dobriban, 2020). "glpc" algorithm, q determined number clusters spectral clustering cluster_leading_eigen function. input graph acyclic, warning message raised, cycle-breaking algorithm applied (see graph2dag details).

title: Estimate a DAG from an input (or empty) graph — SEMdag
text: Two-step extraction optimal DAG input (empty) graph, using step 1) graph topological order bottom-search order, step 2) parent recovery LASSO-based algorithm (FHT, 2010), implemented glmnet.

title: Estimate a DAG from an input (or empty) graph — SEMdag
code: SEMdag(   graph,   data,   LO = "TO",   beta = 0,   eta = 0,   lambdas = NA,   penalty = TRUE,   verbose = FALSE,   ... )

title: Estimate a DAG from an input (or empty) graph — SEMdag
text: graph igraph object graph edges (make_empty_graph(n=0)). data matrix whith n rows corresponding subjects, p columns graph nodes (variables). LO character linear order method. LO="" LO="TL" topological order (resp. level) input graph enabled, LO="BU" data-driven bottom-search vertex (resp. layer) order performed using vertices empty graph. default LO = "". beta Numeric value. Minimum absolute LASSO beta coefficient new direct link retained final model. default, beta = 0. eta Numeric value. Minimum fixed eta threshold bottom-search vertex (eta = 0) layer (eta > 0) ordering. Use eta = NULL, estimation eta adaptively half sample data. default, eta = 0. lambdas vector regularization LASSO lambda values. lambdas NULL, glmnet default using cross-validation lambdas enabled. lambdas NA (default), tuning-free scheme enabled fixing lambdas = sqrt(log(p)/n), suggested Janková van de Geer (2015) many others. reduce computational time provide result run. penalty logical value. Separate penalty factors can applied coefficient. number multiplies lambda allow differential shrinkage. Can 0 variables, implies shrinkage, variable always included model. TRUE (default) weights based graph edges: 0 (.e., edge present) 1 (.e., missing edge) ensures input edges retained final model. FALSE glmnet default enabled (weights equal 1). Note: penalty factors internally rescaled sum p (number variables). verbose logical value. FALSE (default), processed graphs plotted screen. ... Currently ignored.

title: Estimate a DAG from an input (or empty) graph — SEMdag
text: list 3 igraph objects plus vertex ordering: "dag", estimated DAG; "dag.new", new estimated connections; "dag.old", connections preserved input graph; "LO", estimated vertex ordering.

title: Estimate a DAG from an input (or empty) graph — SEMdag
text: extracted DAG estimated using two-step order search approach. First vertex (node) level (layer) order p nodes determined, sort, DAG can learned using step 2) penalized (L1) regressions (Shojaie Michailidis, 2010). estimate linear order obtained priori graph topological vertex () level (TL) ordering, data-driven Bottom-(BU) approach, assuming SEM whose error terms equal variances (Peters Bühlmann, 2014). BU algorithm first estimates last element (terminal vertex) using diagonal entries inverse covariance matrix : t = argmin(diag(Omega)), terminal layer (> 1 vertices) d = diag(Omega)- t < eta. , determines parents L1 regression. eliminating last element (layer) ordering, algorithm applies procedure DAG completely estimated. high-dimensional data (n < p), inverse covariance matrix computed glasso-based algorithm (FHT, 2008), implemented glasso. input graph acyclic, TL, warning message raised, cycle-breaking algorithm applied (see graph2dag details). Output DAG colored: vertices cyan, source nodes, orange, sink nodes, edges gray, present input graph, green, new edges generated LASSO screening.

title: SEM-based differential network analysis — SEMdci
text: Differential Connected Inference (DCI) via sub-network perturbed edges obtained output SEMace, comparable procedure Jablonski et al (2022), SEMrun two-group CGGM solver, comparable algorithm 2 Belyaeva et al (2021). increase efficiency computations large graphs, users can select break network structure clusters, select topological clustering method (see clusterGraph). function SEMrun applied iteratively cluster (size min > 10 max < 500) obtain graph full list perturbed edges.

title: SEM-based differential network analysis — SEMdci

title: SEM-based differential network analysis — SEMdci
text: graph Input network igraph object. data matrix data.frame. Rows correspond subjects, columns graph nodes (variables). group binary vector. vector must long number subjects. vector element must 1 cases 0 control subjects. type Average Causal Effect (ACE) two-group, "parents" (back-door) adjustement set, "direct" effects (type = "ace", default), CGGM solver two-group using clustering method. type = "tahc", network modules generated using tree agglomerative hierarchical clustering method, non-tree clustering methods igraph package, .e., type = "wtc" (walktrap community structure short random walks), type ="ebc" (edge betweeness clustering), type = "fgc" (fast greedy method), type = "lbc" (label propagation method), type = "lec" (leading eigenvector method), type = "loc" (multi-level optimization), type = "opc" (optimal community structure), type = "sgc" (spinglass statistical mechanics), type = "none" (breaking network structure clusters). method Multiple testing correction method. One values available p.adjust. default, method set "BH" (.e., FDR multiple test correction). alpha Significance level (default = 0.05) edge set selection. ... Currently ignored.

title: SEM-based gene set analysis — SEMgsa
text: Gene Set Analysis (GSA) via self-contained test group effect signaling (directed) pathways based SEM. core methodology implemented RICF algorithm SEMrun(), recovering RICF output node-specific group effect p-values, Brown’s combined permutation p-values node activation inhibition.

title: SEM-based gene set analysis — SEMgsa
code: SEMgsa(g = list(), data, group, method = "BH", alpha = 0.05, n_rep = 1000, ...)

title: SEM-based gene set analysis — SEMgsa
text: g list pathways tested. data matrix data.frame. Rows correspond subjects, columns graph nodes (variables). group binary vector. vector must long number subjects. vector element must 1 cases 0 control subjects. method Multiple testing correction method. One values available p.adjust. default, method set "BH" (.e., Benjamini-Hochberg correction). alpha Gene set test significance level (default = 0.05). n_rep Number randomization replicates (default = 1000). ... Currently ignored.

title: SEM-based gene set analysis — SEMgsa
text: list 2 objects: "gsa", data.frame reporting following information pathway input list: ".nodes", pathway size (number nodes); ".DEGs", number differential espression genes (DEGs) within pathway, multiple test correction one methods available p.adjust; "pert", pathway perturbation status (see details); "pNA", Brown's combined P-value pathway node activation; "pNI", Brown's combined P-value pathway node inhibition; "PVAL", Bonferroni combined P-value pNA, pNI; .e., 2* min(pNA, PNI); "ADJP", Adjusted Bonferroni P-value pathway perturbation; .e., min(.pathways * PVAL; 1). "DEG", list DEGs names per pathways.

title: SEM-based gene set analysis — SEMgsa
text: gaining biological insights functional roles pre-defined subsets genes, node perturbation obtained RICF fitting combined - -regulation genes reference interactome obtain overall pathway perturbation follows: node perturbation defined activated minimum among p-values positive; negative, status inhibited. - - regulation genes computed weighted adjacency matrix pathway column sum weights(-1,0,1) source node. overall sum node weights 1, pathway flagged -regulated, otherwise -regulated. combination two quantities allows define direction () gene perturbation. - regulated gene status, associated node inhibition, indicates decrease activation (increase inhibition) cases respect control group. Conversely, - regulated gene status, associated node activation, indicates increase activation (decrease inhibition) cases respect control group.

title: Fit a graph as a Structural Equation Model (SEM) — SEMrun
text: graph igraph object. data matrix whith rows corresponding subjects, columns graph nodes (variables). group binary vector. vector must long number subjects. vector element must 1 cases 0 control subjects. NULL (default), group influence considered. fit numeric value indicating SEM fitting mode. fit = 0 (default), group effect considered. fit = 1, "common" model used evaluate group effects graph nodes. fit = 2, two-group model used evaluate group effects graph edges. algo MLE method used SEM fitting. algo = "lavaan" (default), SEM fitted using NLMINB solver lavaan R package, standard errors derived expected Fisher information matrix. algo = "ricf", model fitted via residual iterative conditional fitting (RICF; Drton et al. 2009), standard error derived randomization bootstrap procedures. algo = "cggm", model fitting based constrained Gaussian Graphical Modeling (CGGM), DAG nodewise Lasso procedure de-biasing asymptotic inference (Jankova & Van De Geer, 2019). start Starting value SEM parameters algo = "lavaan". start NULL (default), algorithm determine starting values. start numeric value, used scaling factor edge weights graph object (graph attribute E(graph)$weight). instance, scaling factor useful weights fixed values (e.g., 1 activated, -1 repressed, 0 unchanged interaction). Fixed values may compromise model fitting, scaling safe option avoid problem. rule thumb, experience, start = 0.1 generally performs well (-1, 0, 1) weights. SE "standard" (default), algo = "lavaan", conventional standard errors computed based inverting observed information matrix. "none", standard errors computed. n_rep Number randomization replicates (default = 1000), permutation flip boostrap samples, algo = "ricf". limit integer value corresponding network size (.e., number nodes). Beyond limit, execution algo = "lavaan" run SE = "none", fit = 0, ridirected algo = "ricf", fit = 1, algo = "cggm", fit = 2. redirection necessary reduce computational demand standard error estimation lavaan. Increasing number enforce lavaan execution algo = "lavaan". ... Currently ignored.

title: Fit a graph as a Structural Equation Model (SEM) — SEMrun
text: list 5 objects: "fit", SEM fitted lavaan, ricf, cggm object, depending MLE method specified algo argument; "gest" "dest", data.frame node-specific ("gest") edge-specific ("dest") group effect estimates P-values; "model", SEM model string algo = "lavaan", NULL otherwise; "graph", induced subgraph input network mapped data variables. Graph edges (.e., direct effects) P-value < 0.05 highlighted red (beta > 0) blue (beta < 0). group vector given, nodes significant group effect (P-value < 0.05) red-shaded (beta > 0) lightblue-shaded (beta < 0); "data", input data subset mapping graph nodes, plus group first column (group specified, column take NA values).

title: Fit a graph as a Structural Equation Model (SEM) — SEMrun
text: SEMrun maps data onto input graph converts SEM. Directed connections (X -> Y) interpreted direct causal effects, undirected, mutual, bidirected connections converted model covariances. SEMrun output contains different sets parameter estimates. Beta coefficients (.e., direct effects) estimated directed interactions residual covariances (psi coefficients) bidirected, undirected, mutual interactions. group variable given, exogenous group effects nodes (gamma coefficients) edges (delta coefficients) estimated. default, maximum likelihood parameter estimates P-values parameter sets computed conventional z-test (= estimate/SE), fits lavaan function, via Maximum Likelihood Estimation (estimator = "ML", default estimator lavOptions). case high dimensionality (n.variables >> n.subjects), covariance matrix semi-definite positive thus parameter estimates done. happens, covariance matrix regularization enabled using James-Stein-type shrinkage estimator implemented function pcor.shrink corpcor R package. Argument fit determines group influence evaluated model, absent (fit = 0), node perturbation (fit = 1), edge perturbation (fit = 2). fit = 1, group modeled exogenous variable, influencing graph nodes. fit = 2, SEMrun estimates differences beta /psi coefficients (network edges) groups. equivalent fit separate model cases controls, opposed one common model perturbed exogenous group effect. fitted, two models compared assess significant edge (.e., direct effect) differences (d = beta1 - beta0). P-values parameter sets computed z-test (= d/SE), lavaan. alternative standard P-value calculation, SEMrun may use either RICF (randomization bootstrap P-values) GGM (de-biased asymptotically normal P-values) methods. algorithms much faster lavaan case large input graphs.

title: Tree-based structure learning methods — SEMtree
text: Four tree-based structure learning methods implemented graph data-driven algorithms.

title: Tree-based structure learning methods — SEMtree
code: SEMtree(   graph,   data,   seed,   type = "ST",   eweight = NULL,   alpha = 0.05,   verbose = FALSE,   ... )

title: Tree-based structure learning methods — SEMtree
text: graph igraph object. data matrix data.frame. Rows correspond subjects, columns graph nodes (variables). seed vector seed nodes. type Tree-based structure learning method. Four algorithms available: "ST"(default). Steiner Tree (ST) identification via fast Kou's algorithm (Kou et al, 1981) connecting set seed nodes (called Terminal vertices) connector nodes (called Steiner vertices) input graph defined graph minimal total distance edges. default edge weights based pairwise correlation, 1-abs(cor(j,k)). input graph E(graph)$weight=1, eweight = "custom", ST seeks minimum subtree (.e., subtree minimal number edges). "CAT". Causal additive trees (CAT) algorithm Jakobsen et al. (2022). argument graph set NULL (.e., input graph needed). first step, (univariate) generalized additive model (GAM) employed estimate residual variances, var(X(j) - [X(j)|X(k)]) j != k, use construct edge weights inputs Chu–Liu–Edmonds’ algorithm (Chow Liu, 1968) recover arborescence. Argument seed must specified analyse subset nodes (variables) interest. "CPDAG". CLE algorithm Skeleton Recovery CPDAG estimation Lou et al. (2021). Together "CAT" algorithm, "CPDAG" data-driven argument graph set NULL. key idea first recover skeleton polytree applying CLE algorithm pairwise sample correlations data matrix. skeleton recovered, set v-structures can correctly identified via simple thresholding approach pairwise sample correlations. CPDAG can found applying iteratively Rule 1 Meek (1995). Argument seed must specified analyse subset nodes (variables) interest. "MST". Minimum Spanning Tree (MST) identification via Prim's algorithm (Prim, 1957). latter finds subset edges includes every vertex graph (defined graph) sum weights edges can minimized. argument seed set NULL (.e., seed nodes needed). eweight Edge weight type igraph object can externally derived using weightGraph user-defined distances. option determines weight--distance transform. set : "NULL" (default), edge weights internally computed equal 1 - abs(pairwise Pearson's correlation). "kegg", repressing(-1), neutral(0) activating(+1) kegg interactions multiplied "zsign" attributes, positive (.e., concordant) values set 1 (minimum distance), negative (.e., discordant) values set 2. "zsign", significant interactions (abs(zsign) > 0) set 1 (minimum distance), non-significant (zsign=0) ones set 2. "pvalue", edge p-value atributes transformed inverse negative base-10 logarithm, 1/(-log(E(graph)$pv)). "custom", algorithm use distance measure specified user "weight" edge attribute input graph. alpha Threshold rejecting pair node independent "CPDAG" algorithm. latter implements natural v-structure identification procedure thresholding pairwise sample correlations adjacent pairs edges appropriate threshold. default, alpha = 0.05. verbose TRUE, shows output tree (recommended large graphs). ... Currently ignored.

title: Tree-based structure learning methods — SEMtree
text: igraph object. type = "ST", seed nodes colored "aquamarine" connectors "white". type = "ST" type = "MST", edges colored "green" present input, graph. type = "CPDAG", bidirected edges colored "black" (algorithm able establish direction relationship x y).

title: Tree-based structure learning methods — SEMtree
text: tree ia acyclic graph p vertices p-1 edges. graph method refers  Steiner Tree (ST), tree undirected graph connect "seed" additional nodes "compact" way possible. data-driven methods propose fast scalable procedures based Chu-Liu–Edmonds’ algorithm (CLE) recover tree full graph. first method, called Causal Additive Trees (CAT) uses pairwise mutual weights input CLE algorithm recover directed tree ("arborescence"). second one applies CLE algorithm skeleton recovery extends skeleton tree ("polytree") represented Completed Partially Directed Acyclic Graph (CPDAG). Finally, Minimum Spanning Tree (MST) connecting undirected graph minimal edge weights can identified. note, input graph directed graph, ST MST undirected trees converted directed trees using orientEdges function.

what: Missing edge testing implied by a DAG with Shipley's basis-set — Shipley.test
title: Missing edge testing implied by a DAG with Shipley's basis-set — Shipley.test
text: Compute P-values d-separation tests implied missing edges given acyclic graph (DAG). conditioning set Z represented, DAG, union parent sets X Y (Shipley, 2000). results every test, DAG, combined using Fisher’s statistic overall test fitted model C = -2*sum(log(P-value(k))), C distributed chi-squared variate df = 2k, suggested Shipley (2000).

title: Missing edge testing implied by a DAG with Shipley's basis-set — Shipley.test
code: Shipley.test(   graph,   data,   MCX2 = FALSE,   cmax = Inf,   limit = 100,   verbose = TRUE,   ... )

title: Missing edge testing implied by a DAG with Shipley's basis-set — Shipley.test
text: graph directed graph igraph object. data data matrix subjects rows variables columns. MCX2 TRUE, Monte Carlo P-value combined C test enabled using R code Shipley extracted <https://github.com/BillShipley/CauseAndCorrelation>. cmax Maximum number parents set, C. parameter can used perform tests number conditioning variables exceed given value. High-dimensional conditional independence tests can unreliable. default, cmax = Inf. limit integer value corresponding graph size (vcount) tolerance. Beyond limit, multicore computation enabled reduce computational burden. default, limit = 100. verbose TRUE, Shipley's test results showed screen (default = TRUE). ... Currently ignored.

title: Missing edge testing implied by a DAG with Shipley's basis-set — Shipley.test
text: list three objects: () "dag":  DAG used perform Shipley test (ii) "dsep": data.frame d-separation tests missing edges DAG (iii) "ctest": overall Shipley's' P-value.

title: Transform data methods — transformData
text: Implements various data trasformation methods optimal scaling ordinal nominal data, help relax assumption normality (gaussianity) continuous data.

title: Transform data methods — transformData
code: transformData(x, method = "npn", ...)

title: Transform data methods — transformData
text: x matrix data.frame (n x p). Rows correspond subjects, columns graph nodes. method Trasform data method. can one following: "npn" (default), performs nonparanormal(npn) semiparametric Gaussian copula model (Liu et al, 2009), estimating Gaussian copula marginally transforming variables using smooth ECDF functions. npn distribution corresponds latent underlying multivariate normal distribution, preserving conditional independence structure original variables. "spearman", computes trigonometric trasformation Spearman rho correlation estimation latent Gaussian correlations parameter nonparanormal distribution (Harris & Dorton (2013), generates data matrix exact sample covariance matrix estimated one. "kendall", computes trigonometric trasformation Kendall tau correlation estimation latent Gaussian correlations parameter nonparanormal distribution (Harris & Dorton (2013), generates data matrix exact sample covariance matrix estimated one. "polychoric", computes polychoric correlation matrix generates data matrix exact sample covariance matrix estimated one. polychoric correlation (Olsson, 1974) measure association two ordinal variables. based assumption two latent bivariate normally distributed random variables generate couples ordinal scores. Tetrachoric (two binary variables) biserial (ordinal numeric variables) correlations special cases. "lineals", performs optimal scaling order achieve linearizing transformations bivariate regression pairwise variables subsequent structural equation models using resulting correlation matrix computed transformed data (de Leeuw, 1988). "mca", performs optimal scaling categorical data Multiple Correspondence Analysis (MCA, .k.homogeneity analysis) maximizing first eigenvalues trasformed correlation matrix. estimates corresponding structural parameters consistent underlying latent space observed variables unidimensional. ... Currently ignored.

title: Transform data methods — transformData
text: list 2 objects returned: "data", matrix (n x p) n observations p transformed variables matrix (n x p) simulate observations based selected correlation matrix. "catscores", category weights "lineals" "mca" methods NULL otherwise.

title: Transform data methods — transformData
text: Nonparanormal trasformation computationally efficient requires one ECDF pass data matrix. Polychoric correlation matrix computed lavCor() function lavaan package. Optimal scaling (lineals mca) performed lineals() corAspect() functions aspect package (Mair De Leeuw, 2008). note, SEM fitting generate data (fake data) must done covariance-based method bootstrap SE, .e., SEMrun(..., algo="ricf", n_rep=1000).

title: Graph weighting methods — weightGraph
code: weightGraph(graph, data, group = NULL, method = "r2z", limit = 10000, ...)

title: Graph weighting methods — weightGraph
text: graph igraph object. data matrix data.frame. Rows correspond subjects, columns graph nodes. group Binary vector. vector must long number subjects. vector element must 1 cases 0 control subjects. default, group = NULL. group NULL, also node weighting actived, node weights correspond attribute: V(graph)$pv (P-value z-test = b/SE(b) simple linear regression y ~ x, .e., lm(node ~ group)) V(graph)$sign (-1 z<-2, +1 z>2, 0 otherwise). method Edge weighting method. can one following: "r2z", weight edges defined using Fisher's r--z transform (Fisher, 1915) test correlation coefficient pairs interacting nodes, group=NULL. Otherwise, difference group r--z trasform tested. Edge weights correspond attribute: E(graph)$pv (P-value z-test) E(graph)$sign (-1 z<-2, +1 z>2, 0 otherwise). "sem", edge weights defined SEM model implies testing group effect simultaneously source sink nodes. new parameter w defined weighted sum total effect group source sink nodes, adjusted node degree centrality. Edge weights correspond attribute: E(graph)$pv (P-value z-test = w/SE(w)) E(graph)$sign (-1 z<-2, +1 z>2, 0 otherwise). available group=NULL. "cov", edge weights defined new parameter w combining group effect source node (mean group difference, adjusted source degree centrality), sink node (mean group difference, adjusted sink degree centrality), source–sink interaction (correlation difference). Edge weights correspond attribute: E(graph)$pv (P-value z-test = w/SE(w) combined difference group source node, sink node, connection) E(graph)$sign (-1 z<-2, +1 z>2, 0 otherwise). available group=NULL. "cfa", edge weights defined CFA1 model implies testing group effect, w latent variable (LV) observed indicators two interacting nodes, fixing loading coefficients residual variances model identification. Edge weights correspond attribute: E(graph)$pv (P-value z-test = w/SE(w) group effect LV) E(graph)$sign (-1 z<-2, +1 z>2, 0 otherwise). available group=NULL. limit integer value corresponding number graph edges. Beyond limit, multicore computation enabled reduce computational burden. default, limit = 10000. ... Currently ignored.
